ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
-Learn to write a proposal and paper format
-Wet lab skills depend fully on your lab.
creating a proposal, conducting a project, and writing a research report

This course allowed me to receive credit for research done in my lab during the academic year. The proposal allowed me to set clear goals for the semester and the end-of-semester write-up of my research provided an opportunity for me to organize my research progress from the year into a concise report and plan for future research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
-Very flexible and doesnt put much restrictions
-Would like to get feedback on my proposal
need more engagement and checkins with lab

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. Great way to get a credit if youre doing lab work anyways. Takes very little work to get the credit and will force you to write and make sure you understand what youre doing.
yes - it's good for getting credit for lab work, but don't expect the course itself to teach you or structure anything.

I would definitely recommend this course to someone who is doing research but not getting paid, but I would advise them that realistically, it could be a significantly larger time commitment than the 10 hours per week required, especially if the work is in a wet lab.
